para.p: The first few Bernoulli polynomials are
The Bernoulli polynomials satisfy the following:

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ k * (x + 1) * (z ^ k / kfactorial)) = (z * e ^ ((x + 1) * z)) / (e ^ z - 1)
((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ k * (x + 1) * (z ^ k / kfactorial))
absent = (z * e ^ ((x + 1) * z)) / (e ^ z - 1)
absent = z * e ^ (x * z) + (z * e ^ (x * z)) / (e ^ z - 1)
absent = z * e ^ (x * z) + (z * e ^ (x * z)) / (e ^ z - 1)
absent = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@((x ^ k * z ^ (k + 1)) / kfactorial) + ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ k * x * (z ^ k / kfactorial))
absent = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@((x ^ k * z ^ (k + 1)) / kfactorial) + ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ k * x * (z ^ k / kfactorial))
absent = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((x ^ (k - 1) * z ^ k) / (k - 1)factorial) + ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ k * x * (z ^ k / kfactorial))
absent = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((x ^ (k - 1) * z ^ k) / (k - 1)factorial) + ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@(B _ k * x * (z ^ k / kfactorial))

The Euler-Maclaurin summation formula is the following. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Hugh L. Montgomery and Robert C. Vaughan, Multiplicative Number Theory I: Classical Theory, p. 500, Theorem B.5. If
< a b
are real numbers,
K
is a positive integer, and
f
is a
C K
function on an open set that contains
[ a , b ]
, then

Math.text: (sum _ (a less m less= b))@(f * m) = ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(f * x * differential-d@(x)) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ K)@(((- 1) ^ k / kfactorial) * (P _ k * b * f ^ (k - 1) * b - P _ k * a * f ^ (k - 1) * a))
(sum _ (a less m less= b))@(f * m)
absent = ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(f * x * differential-d@(x)) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ K)@(((- 1) ^ k / kfactorial) * (P _ k * b * f ^ (k - 1) * b - P _ k * a * f ^ (k - 1) * a))
- ((- 1) ^ K / Kfactorial) * ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(P _ K * x * f ^ K * x * differential-d@(x))
- ((- 1) ^ K / Kfactorial) * ((integral _ a) ^ b)@(P _ K * x * f ^ K * x * differential-d@(x))

nfactorial = n ^ n * e ^ (- n) * square-root@(2 * pi * n) * (1 + O * n ^ (- 1))

Math.text: (list@(f, g)) _ (H ^ s * T) = widehat@(f) * 0 * overline@(widehat@(g) * 0) + (sum _ (n element-of Z set-minus set@(0)))@(widehat@(f) * n * overline@(widehat@(g) * n) * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (2 * s))

para.p:
This is an inner product, with which
⁢
H s
( T )
is a Hilbert space. 6 footnote 6 6 footnote 6 See http://www.math.umn.edu/~garrett/m/mfms/notes/09_sobolev.pdf

For
∈ c
C Z

> s
+ r
1 2
,

Math.tex: \begin{split}&\displaystyle\left\|\sum_{|n|\leq N}c_{n}e^{2\pi inx}\right\|_{C% ^{r}(\mathbb{T})}\\ \displaystyle=&\displaystyle\sup_{0\leq j\leq r}\sup_{x\in\mathbb{T}}\left|% \sum_{|n|\leq N}c_{n}(2\pi in)^{j}e^{2\pi inx}\right|\\ \displaystyle\leq&\displaystyle|c_{0}|^{2}+\sup_{0\leq j\leq r}\sup_{x\in% \mathbb{T}}\left|\sum_{1\leq|n|\leq N}c_{n}(2\pi in)^{j}e^{2\pi inx}\right|\\ \displaystyle\leq&\displaystyle|c_{0}|^{2}+(2\pi)^{r}\sum_{1\leq|n|\leq N}|c_{% n}||n|^{r}\\ \displaystyle=&\displaystyle|c_{0}|^{2}+(2\pi)^{r}\sum_{1\leq|n|\leq N}|c_{n}|% |n|^{s}|n|^{-(r-s)}\\ \displaystyle\leq&\displaystyle|c_{0}|^{2}+(2\pi)^{r}\left(\sum_{1\leq|n|\leq N% }|c_{n}|^{2}|n|^{2s}\right)^{1/2}\left(\sum_{1\leq|n|\leq N}|n|^{-(2s-2r)}% \right)^{1/2}\\ \displaystyle\leq&\displaystyle|c_{0}|^{2}+(2\pi)^{r}\cdot(2\cdot\zeta(2s-2r))% ^{1/2}\cdot\left(\sum_{1\leq|n|\leq N}|c_{n}|^{2}|n|^{2s}\right)^{1/2}.\end{split}
Math.text: (norm@((sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(c _ n * e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x)))) _ (C ^ r * T) = (supremum _ (0 less= j less= r))@((supremum _ (x element-of T))@(absolute-value@((sum _ (absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(c _ n * (2 * pi * i * n) ^ j * e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x))))) less= (absolute-value@(c _ 0)) ^ 2 + (supremum _ (0 less= j less= r))@((supremum _ (x element-of T))@(absolute-value@((sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(c _ n * (2 * pi * i * n) ^ j * e ^ (2 * pi * i * n * x))))) less= (absolute-value@(c _ 0)) ^ 2 + (2 * pi) ^ r * (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(absolute-value@(c _ n) * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ r) = (absolute-value@(c _ 0)) ^ 2 + (2 * pi) ^ r * (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(n) less= N))@(absolute-value@(c _ n) * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ s * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (- r - s)) less= (absolute-value@(c _ 0)) ^ 2 + (2 * pi) ^ r * ((sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(n) less= N))@((absolute-value@(c _ n)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (2 * s))) ^ (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(n) less= N))@((absolute-value@(n)) ^ (- 2 * s - 2 * r))) ^ (1 / 2) less= (absolute-value@(c _ 0)) ^ 2 + (2 * pi) ^ r cdot ((2 cdot zeta) * (2 * s - 2 * r)) ^ (1 / 2) cdot ((sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(n) less= N))@((absolute-value@(c _ n)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(n)) ^ (2 * s))) ^ (1 / 2)

para.p:
This shows that
⁢
H r
( T )
is a reproducing kernel Hilbert space.

Math.text: F * open-interval@(x, y) = (list@(F _ x, F _ y)) _ (H ^ r * T)
F * open-interval@(x, y)
absent = (list@(F _ x, F _ y)) _ (H ^ r * T)
absent = F _ x * y
absent = F _ x * y

para.p:
Thus the reproducing kernel of
⁢
H r
( T )
is 7 footnote 7 7 footnote 7 cf. Alain Berlinet and Christine Thomas-Agnan, Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces in Probability and Statistics, p. 318, who use a different inner product on
⁢
H r
( T )
and consequently have a different expression for the reproducing kernel.
